page.p: The ancient D'ni people have known the Art of Writing for countless millenia, and now this knowledge will be passed on to you! "Linking Through the Ages" was written by TheFloydman and is divided into two main parts:

The first half covers the basics of how to craft Linking Books and Descriptive Books, the means by which you will Link (or warp) to countless Ages--worlds with varying seas, terrains, heavens, and treasures.
More details about how to write better Links can be found in the second half.

Makes it very easy to add new block Pages for use in your Ages. Automatically adds hundreds of vanilla and modded blocks and is completely customizable. More info here.

Ink is the lifeblood of Writing. You will use it to both craft Linking Panels for use in Linking Books and Descriptive Books as well as to copy Pages so that you can use them over and over. There are a couple of different ways to craft Ink Vials:
Because of its usefulness, you will want to stock up on as many Ink Vials as possible.
Ink Mixers are used to craft Linking Panels, which are an essential component in any Linking Book or Descriptive Book. Because of this, your Ink Mixer will be one of your most-used blocks.
You will use your Ink Mixer to combine Ink and Paper into Linking Panels, the gateways through which you will travel to other Ages.

This is the Ink Mixer UI. You may access it by right-clicking an Ink Mixer that has been placed in the world. There are four slots: the two on the left accept Ink Vials and Paper, and the two on the right export Glass Bottles and Linking Panels.
If the center Inkwell is ever empty, it will attempt to pull Ink from an Ink Vial on the left. Removing a Linking Panel from the right side will use up the Ink in the Inkwell.
While the Ink is in the Inkwell, it may be mixed with other items to produce Linking Panels with unique properties.
There have long been rumors of Linking Panels that disarm travelers, maintain their momentum, or even allow them to travel within the same Age. You will need to experiment to see what you can create.
With the Art, there are two main two ways to travel between Ages: Descriptive Books and Linking Books. We'll get to Descriptive Books later, but we'll discuss Linking Books now.
Linking Books do not establish Links to new Ages; rather, they allow you to travel between Ages you already have access to.

When you first craft a Linking Book, it will be Unlinked. Right-clicking an Unlinked Link Book while it is in your dominant hand will bind it to the spot on which it is used. Using that Linking Book at any future time will always return you to the spot it is bound to. You will never be able to change it.

--travel to a new Age without an activated Linking Book to return you home. You can very easily become trapped in an Age if you do not take a Linking Book with you. On very rare occasions (unless you use a specific Page in your Descriptive Book), you may chance upon a Star Fissure that will return you to the overworld, but you cannot depend on that method of travel.

Descriptive Books are the means by which you will travel to new Ages, and the more specific your Descriptive Books are, the more control you will have over which Ages you travel to. In order to write Descriptive Books, you will want Pages, which can be obtained in three ways:
1. they may be purchased from Archivist villagers;
2. they may be found in the Libraries that are scattered throughout the Ages;
3. they may be copied using a Writing Desk;
A Writing Desk will be extremely useful to you as you collect more and more Pages.
This "block" takes up two spaces when placed and will greatly aid your organization, as well as allow you to more specifically define the Links to your Ages.

You may craft a decorative Backboard for your Writing Desk if you would like to add a little flair. It will not change the function of the Writing Desk or grant you any advantages, but you will be the envy of all your fellow Writers.
Apply the Backboard by right-clicking on an already-placed Writing Desk.
The Writing Desk UI is split into two halves.

The left half has 25 slots (each marked with a D'ni numeral), and each slot can hold a Page, Descriptive Book, Collation Folder, or Symbol Portfolio. The full contents of a selected slot will appear in the dark display area.
The right half of the UI has four slots you will interact with.
Placing an Ink Vial in the top-right slot will fill the vertical inkwell and leave a Glass Bottle in the bottom-right slot. You will also need to place paper in the top-left slot with one exception.

To copy any page, right-click it in the dark display area in the left UI, and a copy will appear in the bottom-left slot of the right UI. If the slot contains a Descriptive Book with blank Pages or a Collation Folder, copied Pages will be placed--in order--inside them. Copying to a Descriptive Book with blank Pages also doesn't use up any paper from the top-left slot.
The final step in the Descriptive Book creation process is to craft a Book Binder. This block will allow you to combine all of the Pages you want to include in your Descriptive Book.
Right-click in a placed Book Binder to open its UI. The long skinny box at the top is for naming your Age. The slot on the left is for Leather. The dark display area is where you place Pages.

The first Page you should place is a Linking Panel. All other pages should adhere to the grammar rules explained in the second half of this book. Remember that any essential grammar you omit will be filled in for you.
If you so choose, you may also place Paper into the Book Binder, where it will become blank Pages. These can be filled in using the Writing Desk later.
When you have met all the requirements, a Descriptive Book will appear in the right slot for you to remove to your inventory.
Collation Folders hold an infinite number of Pages in the order in which they are placed, and they cannot be automatically sorted.

They can often be treated like Pages, though, so you may place a Collation Folder in the Book Binder UI (thereby placing all of the Pages therein), or you may empty its contents into a Symbol Portfolio or another Collation Folder.
Symbol Portfolios also hold an infinite number of Pages, but identical Pages within them are stacked. They can be sorted alphabetically.
It is good practice to carry one with you at all times to ensure you have sufficient space to carry any Pages you may encounter.
Bookstands can be used to display and protect Linking Books and Descriptive Books.

When placed in the world, they will face you, no matter which direction you are facing (just like a Sign). Place your Book on a Bookstand, and it will be safe from damage and will not fall to the ground when used.
Lecterns take up a whole block and face one of the four compass directions.

Just like Bookstands, they will protect your Books from damage and will prevent them from falling to the ground when used. Lecterns have the added bonus of being able to display Pages as well as Books.
Portals are a part of everyday life: We already use them to visit places like the Nether and the End. Now Portals can also be used to travel to any Age!
Portals are made up of Crystal blocks, and they may be any size or shape so long as the shape is closed.
To activate a Portal, attach a Book Receptacle to a Portal block on any side but the underside. A Receptacle is easy to craft:
Book Receptacles will accept any activated Linking Book or used Descriptive Book, and they will inherit any special properties from the Linking Panels therein.
WARNING: Portals do not spawn other Portals, so you will need a Portal or a Book in the destination Age to return.
During your exploration, you will no doubt come upon Libraries. These abandoned structures house a Writer's most valuable treasure: Pages!
If you have an incomplete collection of Pages, never pass up the opportunity to plunder a library. You never know what you might find.
Narayni symbols are not limited to only Pages; they can also be written on Banners! All canon Narayani symbols and D'ni numerals can be used as patterns for banners.
Normally these banners are only obtainable in Creative Mode, and most only through the /give command, but they are accessible through the Loom block if you have What Looms Ahead installed.

Libraries get a facelift with More Mystcraft. They function exactly the same, but you may notice they look a bit fancier when you come across them in Ages.
Every once in a while, you will come across a larger building called a Great Library. These structures house much more treasure than their smaller counterparts, but also much more danger.

Due to the way libraries are generated by Minecraft and Mystcraft, you may notice a slight delay when they are replaced with upgraded versions. This is currently unavoidable but shouldn't be too noticeable unless you are flying around.
More Mystcraft adds a few features that can be used in your Ages.
"Pyramids" are a Medium Feature that can be used in your Ages. They accept a Structure Block and will appear worn depending on how unlevel the landscape is.
The "Ocean Monuments" Page allows ocean monuments to spawn in your ages. They are a medium feature, and--due to the current restrictions in their generation--they can only spawn in Deep Ocean biomes.
"Gigantic Trees" are meant to replace "Huge Trees" until their generation is fixed. Gigantic Trees spawn less frequently but are much larger than Huge Trees.
With More Mystcraft installed, you will probably come across some Abandoned Studies in the Overworld. These buildings were once used by a Writer just like you to study the Art and travel to Ages.

You will probably find some supplies inside, as well as some books. Definitely check to see if you are handling a Descriptive Book or a Linking Book. And chances are, if you find an unused Descriptive Book, it will have some blank Pages to which you can copy Symbols using a Writing Desk.
There is also a Page for Abandoned Studies that can be used to add them to an Age.
"Size" Pages are added by More Mystcraft and can only be used by its Pages.

There are five "Size" Pages: Tiny, Small, Medium, Large, and Huge. They work similarly to Length Pages in that they are averaged from left-to-right. There is a limit to how big and how small things can get.
"Tilt" Pages are also unique to More Mystcraft and currently only apply to Tinted Suns.

The three Tilt Pages: No Tilt, Half Tilt, and Full Tilt represent three angles: 0°, 45°, and 90°, respectively. They are averaged left-to-right and determine how tilted a Tinted Sun will appear in its orbit. A Tinted Sun with Full Tilt will circle the horizon and neither rise nor set.
More Mystcraft adds several Biome Distributions for you to use.
"Normal" distributions can be used just like the Tiny, Small, Medium, Large, and Huge Biome Distributions, but instead accept a Size Page.
The "Rings" distribution accepts two or more biomes and creates concentric rings that continue outward forever. The "Boxes" distribution works the same way, except there are right angles.
The "Bands" distributions accept two or more biomes and make infinitely-long bands of each biome.
The "Island" distribution accepts only one biome, and--combined with a "Standard World" Page-- creates realistic island Ages.
The "Maze" distribution accepts two biomes and a Size page. It lays out the biomes in an infinite maze.
"Tinted Suns" are more versatile Suns for truly unique Ages! These Celestials accept all the same inputs as Normal Suns but also several more.
A Size allows you to control the apparent size of the Sun in the sky.
A Tilt allows yo to determine how tilted the orbit of the Sun will be. It can be anywhere from 0° (which passes directly overhead) to 90°, which eternally circles the horizon.
Tinted Suns get their name from their ability to accept a Color. This will allow you to have colorful Suns!

Be warned: Because of the way Mystcraft fills in grammar, it can become confused because Tinted Suns have both an inherent color and a sunset color. If you want to be sure your Tinted Suns comes out right, be sure to explictly define a Sunset Color: Color + Length + Gradient + Sunset Color.
"Cloud Height" Pages are added by More Mystcraft and can be used in any Age.
Just like many other Pages, Cloud Heights are averaged left-to-right when placed together. This gives you ultimate control over where clouds appear in your Age.

The D'ni Guild of Maintainers used special "suits" to visit and evaluate new Ages and also those with suspected dangers.

Maintainer Suits are now available for your use as well. While inside, you will be unable to interact with anything except you own inventory, but you will also be protected from all danger, including void damage.

You will find your sight limited and your movement restrained, but the suit will always link with you. So if you are linking into unknown territory, it is highly recommended that you do so within the protection of a Maintainer Suit:
The grammar of the Art is very easy to understand at the top level. It follows a simple formula:
This means that when arranging Pages, you must always place the Page you want modified after the Page (or Pages) that modify it. For example:
There are several feature Pages that require more than one modifier and some that require none. These are noted in the Quick Guides.

Some modifiers can be combined. For colors, lengths, phases, and directions, two modifiers are averaged to create a custom modifier. If more than 2 modifiers are provided, they are averaged from left-to-right. For example, if your modifiers are organized as
A and B will be averaged to make a new modifier (AB), and AB will be averaged with C to make a new modifier (ABC). This process will continue for as many modifiers are you provide.
In cases where there are two possible averages, phases will cycle forward in time from the first modifier, and directions will cycle clockwise from the first modifier.
"World" Pages let you determine the landscape of an Age. With the exception of "Void World", each one accepts both a Terrain Block and a Sea Block as inputs.
"Cave World" follows similar rules to the Nether but is made of Overworld materials.
"Amplified Normal World" acts like an exaggerated Overworld.
"Flat World" creates a completely flat landscape.
"Void World" is devoid of any landscape at all. There is no ground.
A "Star Fissure" is a rift in the fabric of the universe that generates near an Age's spawn. It is completely harmless and will return you to the Overworld.
"Obelisks" accept one Structure Block and dot the landscape with short towers.
"Surface Lakes" accept one Fluid Block and create shallow pools.
"Deep Lakes" accept one Fluid Block and create deep pools.
"Crystalline Formations" accept one Crystal Block and appear to jut out of the ground.
If you use a "Lacking Small Features" Page, the Age will be devoid of any of these features, but you will also add considerable instability.
Medium Features closely resemble the types of features you encounter in the Overworld.

Nether Fortresses, Villages, Strongholds, Mineshafts, Ravines, and Dungeons all behave similarly to the way they do in the Overworld. However, they may not generate their usual mobs. They do not accept any inputs.
"Spheres" accept a Structure Block and generate at varying sizes and heights, so you will find some both in the ground and floating in the air.
"Spikes" accept a Structure Block and populate the landscape with large round spikes of a single material.
If you use a "Lacking Medium Features" Page, the Age will be devoid of any of these features, but you will also add considerable instability.
"Floating Islands" accept both a Biome and a Structure Block and generate high above the world.
"Tendrils" accept a Structure Block and fill the world with large, flowing tendrils.
Using the "Skylands" page causes the Age to mimic the End in its landscape.
"Caves" generate similarly to the way they do in the Overworld.
"Dense Ores" causes vanilla ores to generate more frequently, which will lead to more instability.
"Huge Trees" generates enormous trees everywhere. This page is NOT server-friendly.
If you use a "Lacking Large Features" Page, the Age will be devoid of any of these features. There is no instability penalty.
Weather Pages allow you to control how the weather behaves in your Ages. Including more than one will cause instability.
Eternal Snow, Rain, and Storm will make it so only that specific weather exists in your Age.
"Eternal Weather" lasts forever, but it is whatever weather is natural to the Age and biome.
Fast, Normal, and Slow Weather behave just like in the Overworld, but at varying speeds.
Overcast Weather doesn't rain, but it does cause the sky to turn gray.
A "No Weather" Page makes it so that it never rains, snows, storms, etc. The sky is whatever color it would normally be without weather.
Suns, Moons, and Stars ("Celestials") accept many of the same modifiers, which affect how each one looks and acts.
The "Dark" variant of each celestial doesn't accept any inputs and makes it so that it can't be seen. It also adds a minute amount of instability.
All non-dark Celestials accept one or more Gradients .
Every normal Celestial plus Twinkling Stars accepts at least one Length and at least one Direction as inputs.
Non-dark Suns and Moons accept at least one Phase as an input, which determines where in its orbit the Celestial will start.
The Art gives you the power to define how light acts in your Age. But beware, your greed may negatively affect the fabric of the Age.
With "Normal Lighting" your Age will light up naturally depending on what Celestials are in the sky.
"Bright Lighting" gives an effect similar to the End, and it will always be too bright for hostile mobs to spawn, even underground. However, it adds a significant amount of instability.
"Dark Lighting" has the opposite effect, and hostile mobs will be able to spawn even at noon. It does not, however, add any instability.
Some choices for your Age are purely cosmetic.
Foliage, Grass, and Water Color Pages all accept at least one Color as an input. You can also use the appropriate "Natural Color" Page as an input instead.
Sky, Night Sky, Cloud, and Fog Color Pages all accept at least one Gradient as an input. You can also use the appropriate "Natural Color" Page as an input instead.
The "Boundless Sky" Page makes it so that the horizon is not rendered. This means that in a Void World you will be able to see Celestials during their entire orbits.
The "Rainbow" Page puts a permament rainbow in the sky. It has no effects but is quite imposing.
Biome Distributions allow you to determine how biomes will be laid out in an Age.
The "Native Biome Distribution" Page does not accept any inputs and copies the rules of the Overworld.
The "Single Biome Distribution" Page accepts one Biome Page as an input, and the entire Age will have the same biome.
The "Grid-form Biome Distribution" Page accepts two or more Biome Pages as inputs and makes a checkerboard pattern. Biomes and landscapes each occupy one square chunk.
The "Tiled Biome Distribution" Page accepts two or more Biome Pages as inputs and makes a checkerboard pattern. Biomes each occupy one square chunk, and landscapes each occupy sixteen square chunks.

The Tiny, Small, Medium, Large, and Huge distributions all accept three or more Biome Pages as inputs. These distributions have blob shapes similar to those of the Overworld, but they have a more standard size, and you get to specify that size.
"Direction" Pages determine at which direction something will start. They are pretty self-explanatory and follow the four compass directions: North, East, South, and West.

Placing multiple Directions together in your Writing will cause them to be averaged from left-to-right. In cases where the average might have two possible values (say, the average of "North Direction" and "South Direction"), the average will be clockwise from the first Direction (so due East in this case).
"Phase" Pages determine at what point a cyclical object is in its cycle.
"Nadir Phase" is the starting point, the equivalent of zero. For Celestials, it corresponds to the place the Overworld Sun would be at midnight. "Zenith Phase" is the opposite.

"Rising Phase" is a quarter of the way through the cycle. For Celestials, this would be where the Sun in the Overworld is rising and is exactly centered on the horizon. "Setting Phase" is the opposite.

Placing multiple Phases together in your Writing will cause them to be averaged from left-to-right. Since Phases are essentially angles (0°, 90°, 180°, 270°), there will be times when two possible averages exist. In these cases, the average will be forward-in-time from the first modifier. So the average of Nadir Phase (0°) and Zenith Phase (180°) would be Rising Phase (90°).
"Length" Pages determine how long something will last. Their exact meaning, however, depends on the context in which they are used.
Every "Length" Page is defined by the value of the "Full Length" Page. If it has a value of 1, "Double Length" is 2, "Half Length" is 0.5, and "Zero Length" is 0.
For Celestials, "Full Length" has a value of 24,000 ticks, the length of a full day in the Overworld.
For Gradients, "Full Length" has a value of 12,000 ticks, the length from sunrise to sunset in the Overworld.
Placing multiple Lengths together in your Writing will cause them to be averaged from left-to-right. This means you will never end up with a Length greater than 2 or less than 0.
Several effects can be added to your Ages to make them more exciting. They also affect instability.
Some events in Minecraft--like crops growing--depend on how often a specific block is randomly called. The "Accelerated" Page causes accelerates the pace of these events. Adds some instability.
Adding "Lightning" to your Age will cause consistent lightning strikes but will lower the overall instability.
The "Meteors" Page will cause meteors to rain down on your Age but will also reduce its instability.
"Scorched Surface" makes the surface of your Age so hot that mobs and players will catch fire! Reduces instability.
The "Spontaneous Explosions" Page will cause random explosions to occur throughout your Age but will also reduce instability.
Sixteen "Color" Pages are available in Mystcraft. Each one explains itself, but we must address how they are combined.
Just like other modifiers like Lengths and Directions, Colors are averaged from left-to-right when they are placed next to each other. Because of this, the order of your Colors is very important.
For example, if you use Red Color + Blue Color + White Color, you will end up with a Pinkish Purple because Red and Blue make Deep Purple, and Deep Purple and White make Pinkish Purple.
But if you instead do Red Color + White Color + Blue Color, you will end up with a Medium Purple because Red and White make Pink, and Pink and Blue make Medium Purple.
Remember that you can place the same Color many times in a row, so Green Color + White Color + White Color will make a very Light Green.

Gradients are a powerful tool of the Art used to change colors over time. They accept both a Color and a Length as inputs. Multiple Gradients can then be combined to switch from one Color to the next.

Color + Length + Gradient are interpreted as, "Show this color at the start of this time, and slowly transition to the next color over the Length." For gradients, "Full Length" translates to 12,000 ticks instead of the 24,000 used for Celestials.

For example, if you use Red Color + Full Length + Gradient + Green Color + Half Length + Gradient, the color will start at red, and over the course of 12,000 ticks transition to green. Then over the course of 6,000 ticks it will transition back to red and repeat.
Gradient transtions will continue even if they are not visible, so you need to be aware of the timings of things like sunsets.
These are just some random thoughts that need to be addressed somewhat.
In Creative Mode you will find you have access to an "Anti-PVP" page. This prevents players from attacking one another in an Age.

The "Clear Modifiers" Page is 100% unnecessary in the 1.12 versions of Mystcraft. It is present only to increase compatibility with Ages from previous versions. If you are creating Ages from scratch, it is best to steer clear of it entirely.

Beware of instability. If you write conflicting grammar or get too greedy in your Writing, you will likely link to an unstable Age. Some Ages are so unstable their very fabric begins to tear apart. Learn from your mistakes.
This Quick Guide should be a great reference when you are deciding how to define your Links. Use them to determine the order in which you should put your Pages.
Red text points out which Pages add instablity.
Green text points out which Pages add stablity.
Group titles followed by "(1)" mean that if you add more than one Page of that type, it will add instablity to the Age.
*Each "+" represents a required modifier. You can add more.
*You can add as few or as many modifiers as you would like.
Any mods you have installed may add modifiers, especially for biomes and blocks.
